abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory, sustainability is likely,
            institutional development impact is substantial, and Bank
            and Borrower performances are satisfactory. Several lessons
            can be derived from the implementation of this project. Some
            are summarized as follows: 1) The experience in Uruguay
            showed that CREMA contracts (Contracts for Rehabilitation
            and Maintenance Departments Intendencias) are powerful
            instruments to carry out road maintenance and rehabilitation
            in an efficient and effective way even in a situation of
            great budgetary pressure. 2) In the case of Uruguay, the
            commitment of the government to maintenance was essential to
            avoid serious damage to the road assets caused by
            maintenance neglect, but the current government's
            pledge to provide adequate funds for road maintenance does
            not commit succeeding governments. The issue of a more
            stable funding mechanism cannot be deleted from the agenda.
            3) The Ministry of Transport and Public Works (MTOP)
            ownership of, and commitment to the outsourcing policies
            supported by the project were critical to their success at a
            time of unprecedented economic crisis. The project suggests,
            however, some interesting lessons regarding the overall
            impact of government funding decisions on the reform process
            as it exposes the tension between immediate stabilization
            needs and better fiscal outcomes. The decline in sector
            funding, and equally important the uncertainties with regard
            to future levels of funding, forced MTOP to slow down the
            implementation of various institutional initiatives that
            were being tested with promissory results. 4) It resulted
            that the degree of internalization of the technical
            assistance recommendations varied among the Intendencias
            according to the level of interest shown by their respective
            leaders. This suggests that future technical assistance
            programs should be demand-driven and tailored to the
            specific priorities of the Intendencias requesting support,
            even if such an approach may face some political
            sensitivities. 5) The successful departmental road
            maintenance program should be fine-tuned to further its
            impact on institutional building. This program should be
            supplemented with an incentive framework that leads the
            Intendencias to greater efficiency and effectiveness.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Transport Project for Uruguay
            aims to a) rehabilitate and upgrade elected national roads
            and bridges to MERCOSUR (the regional agreement between
            Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Ururguay) standards; b)
            increase private sector participation in maintaining and
            rehabilitating national road systems; and c) strengthen road
            sector management. There are 5 components. The first, road
            rehabilitation and bridge restoration, reinforces the
            pavement structures of national roads and strengthens,
            widens, or replaces existing bridges. Component 2 uses
            performance-based CREMA contracts (contracts for
            rehabilitation and maintenance) to rehabilitate and maintain
            road networks. Component 3, funded by the National
            Directorate of Highway's (DNV), consists of a contract
            maintenance program and incremental operational costs of
            force account maintenance activities managed by field
            districts. Component 4 caries out departmental maintenance
            subprojects over the project period in the participating
            departments. The last component 1) strengthens the technical
            capacity of the ministry of transport and public works in
            road financing and user-charge areas, strengthens the
            DNV's institutional and operational capacity, and
            transfers technology to and strengthens the maintenance
            management practices of participants in the Departmental
            Roads Maintenance program; and 2) improves pavement markings
            and road signs along highways and implements a pilot program
            for road safety.
